titleStmt.title: A tru[e] relati[on] of the pro[cee]dings of the Bauarian and Spa[nish] forces before the city Heydelburgh hauing very strongly besiedged it. As also, the marching of the King of Bohemia and Count Mansfield, with their forces into Alsatia, belonging to Leopoldus the emperours brother, and the Duke of Brunsvvicke into Bauaria. Likewise, the newes from most of the prouinces of Europe, that therein you may behold, the afflicted estate of Christendome, with the various changes whereunto man is subiected.

titleStmt.title: A tru[e] relati[on] of the pro[cee]dings of the Bauarian and Spa[nish] forces before the city Heydelburgh hauing very strongly besiedged it. As also, the marching of the King of Bohemia and Count Mansfield, with their forces into Alsatia, belonging to Leopoldus the emperours brother, and the Duke of Brunsvvicke into Bauaria. Likewise, the newes from most of the prouinces of Europe, that therein you may behold, the afflicted estate of Christendome, with the various changes whereunto man is subiected.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
A TRV ‚Ä¢ RELATI ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ OF THE PRO ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
dings of the Bauarian and Spa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ forces before the City Heydelburgh, hauing very ≈øtrongly be≈øiedged it.
AS ALSO, The marching of the King of Bohemia and Count Mansfield, with their forces into Allatia, belonging to Leopoldus the Emperours brother, and the Duke of Brun≈øwicke into Bauaria.
LIKEWISE, The newes from mo≈øt of the Prouinces of Europe, that therein you may behold, the afflicted e≈øtate of Chri≈øtendome, with the Various Changes whereunto man is ≈øubiected.
Printed the 11. of Iulii. Sua cuique mihi mea.
At LONDON, Printed for Nicholas Bourne, and Thomas Archer, and are to be ≈øold at the Royall Exchange, and Popeshead-Pallace. 1622.

div.head: The fir≈øt letter from Con≈øtantinople, the 10. of Iune 1622.
div.p: VVE vnder≈øtand from Tartaria that there is great mu≈øtering of men, and that they intend to challenge the Throne of Othoman, hauing heard of the death of O≈øman, the great Turke: for this it ≈øtands, all that va≈øt Countrey from Ru≈ø≈øia to the Indian and Atlantick Seas, is diuided betwixt three chames of ancient and noble race: The fir≈øt is called Tartar Cham, a mighty Emperor, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the Prouince Mangia be≈øides diuers other great Countreyes: The ≈øecond Tartar Mechrit, vnder whom is de≈øertum de lop; and many Nations to the Ca≈øpian Sea. The third is Tartar Chrim, di≈øcending directly from the Family of Othoman, who both by birth and contract may challenge the Imperiall Crown of Turkey, if that line ≈øhall faile, as is thought that he will doe now, or otherwi≈øe reuenge the murther of the afore≈øaid O≈øman vpon the Ianni≈ø≈øaries.

Al≈øo the Letters from Venice make mention that ≈øome of the principall offenders that layed their hands on the Emperor, are fled, and that the re≈øt at home are diuided, ≈øome holding with Mu≈øtapha, and ≈øome with a yonger brother of O≈øman afore≈øaid. And that Mu≈øtapha de≈øires not the Empire, longing onely to vi≈øit the Temple of Mecha, being raui≈øhed with the promi≈øes of Mahomet.

They write al≈øo, that the principall Mu≈øty, and ≈øome Doctors of the Law, haue fore-told and pre≈øaged the determination, and finall end of the Turki≈øh greatne≈ø≈øe, per≈øwading the Vi≈øirs at the imitation of the Graecians, euery one to ≈øtep in for a Kingdome, or more.

From Per≈øia they certifie vs, that notwith≈øtanding, through this di≈ø≈øention in Turkey, they haue gotten good opportunity to recouer Tauris, and other places left; the Sophy being much di≈øplea≈øed with the in≈øolent murther of the great Turke (as one Prince may act anothers part) is onely re≈øolued to rai≈øe an army, to be reuenged on the Ianni≈ø≈øaires, wherevpon the Beglerbeg of Arabia hath ≈øent him a pre≈øent of diuers braue Hor≈øes.

From Alexandria we heare, that the plague is ≈øo great in Gran Cayro, that about 80000. there haue beene buried within the ≈øpace of foure moneths, and that the Iewes are flocking in ≈øuch numbers to the Sea Townes, whereby the traffick is much augmented, and increa≈øed in the Straites.

From Algier they write, that the Pirate begin to erect a Common wealth among them≈øelues, and haue written to the Hollanders, that if they will vnite with their forces together, they will make an notable attempt vpon the dominions of the King of Spaine, and begin a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there.

It is reported here that at Naples there hath been an attempt made vpon the Viceroy by the Nobility and inhabitants, being perplexed with a dearth: but they cry out vpon nothing ≈øo much as liberty, and lye in waite to put ≈øome thing in execution.

The≈øe that come from Rome, relate that the Pope hath giuen a free indulgence and pardon of ≈øinnes to all them that will ≈øerue the Emperour in his wars, wherupon many ≈øouldiers and great ≈øtore of money are ≈øent vnto him.

The Signorie of Venice hath ≈øent lately diuers Gallies at Sea, be≈øides ≈øome Gulleons towards Candia, and fortified the Harbours in Hi≈øtria and Dalmatia, and vpon the continent about Crema and Bre≈øcia, prouideth all the places of importance with ≈øtrong garri≈øons.

Letters of Millane make mention, that there hath beene an in≈øurrection among≈øt the Gri≈øons, whereby diuers Spaniards and Imperiali≈øts haue beene ≈ølaine, and many places for≈øaken, not without great terrour of the re≈øt.

From Genoa it is certified, that ≈øome vndertakers haue taken ≈øanctuary, or A≈øylum, being denied a protection from Spaine, although they ≈øay their debts ari≈øe, for being engaged about the Catholike Kings affaires.

They write from Florence and Luca, that there is great complaint again≈øt the Engli≈øh, ≈øeeing they deale not for ≈øo many ≈øilkes as they were v≈øed to doe; and therefore they will endeauour to make cloth and cottens of their owne, and not trade with England, as in times pa≈øt.

From Poland the Newes is, that the Ie≈øuites are hatefull to the Inhabitants, wherupon the Lords of the Country haue petitioned to the Maie≈øtie of Sigi≈øm ‚Ä¢ nd, either to bani≈øh, or di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them, about which there is great di≈øcontent occa≈øioned: and heere giue me leaue a little by way of trans≈øition to wonder at this generation, why they? ouer all the Orders of Religion ≈øhould ≈øo far vary from true Religion, as to delight in murther, combu≈øtion of Kingdomes, o≈øtentation of knowledge, rapture of vi≈øi ‚Ä¢ ns, and e≈øpecially ≈øetting Princes at divi≈øion, yea breaking the band of amitie betweene Prince and Subiect, ≈øure I can yeeld you no r ‚Ä¢ a≈øon for it? but this as it fareth with Children, who ≈øucking of a froward nur≈øes brea≈øt become accordingly froward and petti≈øh in their liues: ≈øo they having one Ignatius Loyalta a Souldier to their Father of a fiery di≈øpo≈øition, no doubt according to his name, doe immitate him in the fierie and bloody ≈øtepps of warre and di≈ø≈øention: God grant that all Princes
may take heede of their pollicies. For in my Con≈øcience they would pull down the Papacy, if they could, and ≈øet vp their owne Superintendancy.

They al≈øo write, that from the Cittie of Leopolis and the Country adiacent, much Corne hath beene tran≈øported to Constantin ‚Ä¢ ple in this time of their dearth through the Blacke Sea, whereby they haue beene wonderfully enriched, as the Turkes neighbourly are releived.

From Spaine, there is newes of the feare of the Mores, who haue lately made an attempt in Granado, and word is brought by a Brazill man into Portingall, that the wilde men about the River of Amazones, haue rebelled again≈øt the Portingals, and Spaniards, who governe the Country and rule there. Much like that vnfortunate mi≈øchiefe which hath happened of late in Virginia‚ñ™ where we heare almo≈øt 300. of the Engli≈øh Plantation were ≈ølaine by the perfidiou≈ønes of the old Inhabitants.

The ≈øecond, from Vienna the 22, day, This Cit ‚Ä¢ ie is much quieted ≈øince the Emperours
Marriage, for heere are many Nobles and Ladies, who profe≈ø≈øe the Go≈øpel, and haue their Congregations without the walles of the Cittie, to the number ≈øometime of fortie or fiftie Coaches, all which liue here vndi≈øturbed by rea≈øon the Empere≈ø≈øe entertaines them graciou≈øly, and they attend the Court with all humilitie when occa≈øion ≈øerveth; whereas before they ≈øtood vppon their guard, and their Servants rodd with pi≈øtols and petronels to the Church: And (God be thanked) the Ie≈øuites cannot divert him from his re≈øolution, to keepe good quarter with his Subiects, although they haue many times attempted the ≈øame. Or other wi≈øe it may be, their great numbers keepe all in awe, and that the Emperour is loath to be troubled with warres abroad, and di≈ø≈øentions at home.
From Odenburgh, is here newes that the Emperour propo≈øed to the Lords and States, the Coronation of his Sonne, but that they ab≈øolutely denyed it, as having made choice of another.

It was al≈øo Reported, that the Co≈øackes having no Warres in Poland, threatned to come downe into Hungaria, which the Ie≈øuits vrged, and the Emperour intertayned, but it is ≈øayd, and thought, the Tartarians and Ru≈ø≈øians will keepe them backe with their Incur≈øions and Enterpri≈øes, which they intend to make ≈øhortly.

In tho≈øe parts are ≈øtill made great mu≈øterings, to ≈øupply the Emperours warres. This Cittie, Prague it ≈øelfe, hath guard and watch like a Towne of warre, and they beate vnto the Parado, as if the enemie lay before it. In plaine termes, they are iealous one of another, and the Heires and Friends of tho≈øe whom the Emperour put to execution, long to be revenged. As for the Iewes, though they generally reioyce at tho≈øe di≈ø≈øentions among Chri≈øtians, and ≈ølaughtering one another, yet doe they particularly rather fauour the Prote≈øtants then the Catholiques.

From Moravia, wee vnder≈øtand that the
Marquis of Iaggerendorf, remayneth con≈øtant to the King of Bohemia, and hath written to Count Mansfield for his comming into Bavaria, alledging if hee doe attempt that, he ≈øhall be ≈øure to finde many Friends for his pa≈ø≈øage into Bohemia, where, if the warre beganne againe, no que≈øtion, ≈øome great alteration will follow: for Bethlem Gabor is now at lea≈øure to take his part, and will que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, if he can pro≈øecute any cour≈øe to come neere him.

The fourth, from Cullen the fir≈øt of Iuly. The Baron of Anholt hath threatned the Countrey of the Landtgraue of He≈ø≈øen, in behalfe of the Imperiali≈øtes; hee intends to recover the places in W ‚Ä¢ ≈øtphalia, taken by the Duke Chri≈øtian of Brun≈øwick, but the Inhabitants are all rather for Brun≈øwick, then the Bi≈øhop of Cullen, from whom they were taken.

From Franckfort we vnder≈øtand, that the Duke of Saxony hath impo≈øed a har≈øh Commandement in his Townes, for the
≈øearching of Pa≈ø≈øengers, and although he ≈øeemeth di≈øcontent at Bavaria's proceedings, yet doth he governe Sile≈øia for the Emperour, or at lea≈øt ≈øo much of it as the Catholiques are willing to ≈øubmit vnto him. But among other things, the Bi≈øhops are mo≈øt fierce again≈øt the Prote≈øtants, and will not ≈øuffer them to goe vnto their Churches.

From Poland we haue Newes, that the inhabitants being become loath of the Ie≈øuits, the Nobilitie hath reque≈øted the King, either to bani≈øh or di≈ømi≈ø≈øe them, about which is great di≈øcontent occa≈øioned.

They write from Noragrad in Ru≈ø≈øia, that the Ie≈øuites had layd a plott with certaine Pru≈ø≈øians, to robbe and ≈øurpri≈øe the Abbey of Saint Nuclay in Mu≈øcovia, adioyning almo≈øt to the Sea, which they did either out of envie, at the flouri≈øhing of the Greeke Church, then which there is nothing more hatefull to the Roman, or out of a common di≈øpo≈øition, and
wicked perver≈øene≈ø≈øe to rai≈øe quarrels betweene Countries, and nouri≈øh enmitie betweene Princes.

The la≈øt from Franckfort, the fir≈øt of Iuly. After the arrivall of the Duke of Brun≈øwick at Mainhem, where he was ≈øtately well-commed; the King of Bohemia ≈øeeing the Countrey was not able to ≈øu≈øtaine his Forces, called a Coun≈øell of Warre, and re≈øolved to depart; leaving the Palatinate to the care and tuition of the Lord Belfa≈øt, and Generall Vere; with whom he al≈øo left eight thou≈øand men more then they had, and ≈øo they devided them≈øelues, that they pre≈øently marched ten thou≈øand hor≈øe, and twentie thou≈øand Foote.

The King and Mansfeild ar now in Al≈ø ‚Ä¢ tia, pro≈øecuting the Warre there again≈øt the Emperours Brother Leopaldus, burning, ≈øpoyling, and taking the Countrey to his obedience, the which will con≈øtraine Tilly ≈øoone to for≈øake the ≈øiege of Heidelburge, and follow the King, and ≈øo by this
meanes divert the Warre into his Enemies Countrey: He hath ≈øent the Duke of Brun≈øwick into Bavaria, to furni≈øh the Kings Armie with provi≈øion, and then to march and ioyne both together, and ≈øo to goe forward as toward Bohemia, as God ≈øhall giue them leaue. They were no ≈øooner gone, but Tilly advanced his Forces towardes Ladenburgh, and from thence to Heidelburgh. Whereupon Sir Garret Herbert Commaunder there of the Ca≈øtle, a≈ø≈øembled the Burgers and Inhabitants to know both their abilitie, and re≈øolutions, whether they would endure the ≈øiege or no, & how long they thought their provi≈øion would la≈øt: they an≈øwered generally, that they would liue and die with him, and ≈øo they prepared them≈øelues to endure the ≈øiege. And it was thought that Tilly did this rather to divert them from their Iourney into Al≈øatia, then to be≈øtow ≈øo much time in the ≈øiege of a Towne which could profit him l ‚Ä¢ ttle in the obtaining more, then the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the place, vnle≈ø≈øe the Emperour were
re≈øolued contrary to his owne Emba≈ø≈øy, to make it a continuall warre. Tilly going on with his ≈øiege, tooke two of the inhabitants, and cut off their heads, which he pitched vpon poles, turning their faces toward the towne to terrifie the Burgers: but they in requitall cut off fiue ≈øouldier‚ñ™ heads, & ≈øerued them ≈øo likewi≈øe. Gon≈øales in the meane time being at Opp ‚Ä¢ nheim, was yet doubtfull whether he would ≈øet vpon Mainheim or Frankendale, and ≈øo to get the Palatinate at once, le≈øt it be gotten againe: but there is a God that holdeth the windes in his hands, and will no doubt hold backe that re≈øolution, which mu≈øt be the cau≈øe of ≈øo much blood-≈øhedding, if the warres ≈øhould goe forward in ≈øuch a manner: but what will be the i≈ø≈øue, time will reueale.

The Landgraue of He≈ø≈øen, mi≈øtru≈øting lately the forraging of his countrey by the Imperials, writ to the Princes of the vnion concerning the ≈øame, who all returned, that their cau≈øe was a common feare, and therefore they would liue and die together in maintaining the generall
cau≈øe of Religion, and particular defending one anothers Countrey.

In the ≈øame Letter was likewi≈øe ≈øet downe the re≈øolution of diuers Imperiall Cities, viz. Au≈øpurg, Norremburg, Wittenburg, Francfort, Strasburg, and ≈øome other, for the maintaining of the confe≈ø≈øion of Au≈øpurg, which was the re≈øolution of the Prote≈øtant Faith, bought out long ≈øince by great ≈øummes of Money of Rodolphus and Matthias, former Emperors. Whereupon the≈øe Cities fortified their walls, had their Burgers in Armes, for feare to bee ≈øurprized.

We haue heard from Hagenaw, that the Imperials had lately gone about to ≈øurprize the ≈øaid Citie, and had gotten fortie men through a Vault within the Walls, but were all pre≈øently ≈øhot to death, and the Citie pre≈øerued of that dangerous enterpri≈øe.

In Hungaria the matters ≈øtand yet doubtfull: the Hungarians haue flatly denyed the Coronation of the Emperors ≈øonne: the Clergie de≈øires to haue all the Spirituall goods backe againe, with the arrerages,
but the States and Lay-men will re≈øtore them but a part. They can neyther agree vpon many other points: ≈øo that it is likely nothing will be concluded at the Dyet.
Here was flying newes, that the Emperor was taken pri≈øoner, but it is not true: but this is certaine, Bethlem Gabor and the Lord Bridiani are very ≈øtrongly marched vp in armes.

Tho≈øe of Glatz and Klingenburgh ≈øtand yet brauely out, and haue lately giuen a great Ouerthrow vnto the Imperialli≈øts, and they grow daily ≈øtronger & ≈øtronger. The old Count of Thorne is reported to be vpon the way with 26000. men, to re≈øcue them.

From Denmarke they write, that the King hath ≈øent diuer≈øe Pre≈øents to the Queene of Bohemia at the Hage, and written ≈øundry Letters of comfort & con≈øolation, a≈ø≈øuring of his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance as wel of Men as Money: and that hee hath reque≈øted the Hauen Townes to arme diuers Souldiers to goe into Westphalia, to helpe and ≈øupply tho≈øe garri≈øons which Brun≈øwick left there.

The Hollanders lately come from Sweden report, that the Captaine of Calmar ca≈øtle was called in que≈øtion for his life, as b ‚Ä¢ ing betrayed by a counterfeit letter, written by ≈øome ≈øecret malitious enemy, as though the ≈øame came from Poland for the ≈øurrendring of the fort when time ≈øhould ≈øerue: but his innocency ≈øaued his life, and the matter was ≈øoone taken vp.

From France it is written, that the king is re≈øolued to go forward in his enterpri≈øes again≈øt the Prote≈øtant townes. That the Ie≈øuites are iealous of the Prince of Conde, and he gets but the kings di≈øplea≈øure by his violent cour≈øes. That the Prote≈øtants will rather make ≈øallies and die in the field then in their hou≈øes. That Mountalbo is ≈øo well prouided of all kind of proui≈øion, that they thinke the king will not ea≈øily b ‚Ä¢ ≈øiege it againe. Tho≈øe of Mompellier prepare them≈øelues likewi≈øe, if his Maie≈øtie would attempt any thing again≈øt them.

That the Duke of Rohan increa≈øe ‚Ä¢ h his army dayly, and hopeth vpon a great per≈øon in France. That the king is much
di≈øcontented, and hath a growing di≈øea≈øe vpon him. That the Rochellers take dayly prizes, and were re≈øolued to make a ≈øally vpon the Duke of E≈øpernon, being ≈øtrong and able to mini≈øter many braue ≈øouldiers. That there is a prohibition for the landing of the Engli≈øh at Callice, or on tho≈øe Coa≈øts. That diuers Apologies are written in the defence of the Prote≈øtants, and that the Queene laboureth what ≈øhe may to pacifie the troubles.

From B ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ ≈øels they write, that if the Amba≈ø≈øadours doe not ≈øuddenly agree vpon a peace, it is feared that the warre ‚Ä¢ will increa≈øe both in the Palatinate, and the Low Countries. My Lord of A ‚Ä¢ gile hath almo≈øt filled his Regiment, and they lo ‚Ä¢ ke for foure or fiue thou≈øand Brit
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ more to come vnto them within this „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ i ‚Ä¢ weekes.

From the Hag ‚Ä¢
we heare, that the Prince of O ‚Ä¢ ang is marched vp with a braue army, with re≈øolution to ≈øet downe b ‚Ä¢ fore Shertog ‚Ä¢ nb ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ h, & hath ≈øent for all his Captaines out of England to attend his ≈øeruice ‚Ä¢ no que≈øtion S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eola will follow him. Wee
heare al≈øo, that there are publicke Fa≈øts and ≈øet Prayers for the affaires of the Palatinate.

They write al≈øo, that his ≈øubiects of Austria, Stiria, Curniola, and Curinthia, haue petitioned to his Mai≈øtie, that as they proue good and obedient ≈øubiects vnto him, it would plea≈øe him to be a gratious Lord vnto them, to giue them leaue to liue in the libertie of their con≈øcience, and die in the profe≈ø≈øion of the Go≈øpel, that liuing and dying they may giue God the prai≈øe for his protection, who openeth the hearts of kings, and his Maie≈øtie the honour of their welfare, for being ≈øo beneficiall vnto them.
